utterances: Comedy-deprived moviegoers are desperate for the return of the old Woody Allen - the one who made them laugh.
Each new Allen film is frantically examined.
Is he back?
Please let him be back.
But ""Vicky Cristina Barcelona"" is not the return of Woody Allen.
Elvis has truly left the building.
Vicky Cristina Barcelona"" is, unsurprisingly, the story of two young American women, Vicky and Cristina, who spend the summer in Barcelona.
Vicky, played by Rebecca Hall, is grounded and realistic - she's engaged to be married - while Cristina, played by Scarlett Johansson, is into suffering, passion and risk.
It's Cristina, naturally, who catches the eye rogue painter of Juan Antonio, played by Javier Bardem.
He's an unabashed seducer who doesn't hesitate to chat them both up.
(Soundbite of movie, ""Vicky Cristina Barcelona"")
(as Juan Antonio) I'd like to invite you both to come with to Obiello(ph).
(as Vicky) To come where?
(as Juan Antonio) To Obiello.
We leave in one hour.
(as Vicky) You're asking us to fly to Obiello and back?
(as Juan Antonio) No. We'll spend the weekend.
We'll eat well, we'll drink good wine.
We'll make love.
(as Cristina) Yeah, who exactly is going to make love?
(as Juan Antonio) Hopefully the three of us.
No matter what you end up thinking about ""Vicky Cristina Barcelona,"" it's hard not be entertained by the Oscar-winning Bardem, who eats this role up like it's a hot fudge sundae.
The problem is that ""Vicky Cristina Barcelona"" is too intent on being taken seriously, to be more than mildly diverting.
Allen himself said in interviews that this was a film about relationships, not a comedy - and he's right.
Some of Allen's best work bridges the gap between humor and drama, but ""Vicky Cristina Barcelona"" has neither the humor nor the insights to make this happen.
Despite its focus on the romantic entanglements of innocents abroad, this film barely rises to the level of Henry James lite.
There is nothing wrong with Allen's intention to marry comedy to emotion.
It's simply too bad that he's not as good at it as he used to be.
Kenneth Turan reviews movies for MORNING EDITION and the Los Angeles Times.
You can see clips of ""Vicky Cristina Barcelona,"" and decide a little bit by yourself at NPR.org.

I'm Ira Flatow.
This week, a team of researchers confirmed, for the first time with conclusive evidence, that a mother can pass cancer to her baby in the womb.
It's an unfortunate family story.
The mother eventually died from the cancer.
But an extremely rare occurrence, the first reported case of a mother passing cancer to her baby, was way back in 1866.
And since then there have been fewer than two dozen suspected cases, all based on circumstantial evidence.
And now for the first time we have genetic proof that such a thing is possible, but probably not something any mothers out there who are pregnant should be worrying about.
So what can medical researchers learn from a fluke case like this?
My next guest is one of the authors on the research paper in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences this week.
Dr. Tony Ford, senior scientist on the childhood leukemia team at the Institute of Cancer Research in London.
Welcome to Science Friday, Dr. Ford.
Thank you very much for the invitation.
It's a pleasure to speak to you.
Thank you.
How did all this get started?
How was it discovered, this case?
Well, this case was started when an 11-month-old girl was admitted to a clinic in Japan with a large tumor on her cheek.
And initially the clinicians there thought that this was going to be a solid sarcoma that often occurs in young children.
And it turned out that when she was being biopsied, the father said that just a few months earlier his wife had died from leukemia.
And initially the guys in Japan thought that this would be just maybe a cancer-prone family, which does happen from time to time.
But after they had done a biopsy on the cheek, they realized that it wasn't a solid sarcoma, it was, in fact, a lymphoma.
And then the guys, of course, thought that this could well be a secondary sort of tumor that may have arisen from the mother's cancer, which was very similar.
Right.
